## Pull a list of column names from the object fragility23 into one list
```{r}
names(x = fragility23)
```
## You want to see the types of data that are included in the data such as num or characters
```{r}
str(object = fragility23)
```
```{r}
head(x = fragility23,10) #Show only the first 10 rows, in the order they appear in the object
```
```{r}
tail(fragility23,10) #Show only the first 10 rows, in the order they appear in the object
```

```{r}
fragility23[,c(5,11,9)] #Limit your data to exclude those columns you wont be working with, which keeps the data more manageable in R. Include the number for each column you want to keep. 
```
```{r}
fragility23[,c('S1: Demographic Pressures','P1: State Legitimacy','E2: Economic Inequality')] #A better option for limiting columns is to use column names instead of numbers which can be miscounted, example below
```
```{r}
grep(pattern = "Country|S1|P1|E2|Total",x = names(fragility23),fixed = F,value = T) #Search the data for certain strings of text, you can even shorten the search of the string like instead of Total use Tot
```
```{r}
keep=grep("Country|S1|P1|E2|Total",names(fragility23),fixed = F,value = T)
frag23_sub=fragility23[,keep] #indicate what you are keeping for strings for a data object for transformation and give this object a new name as a subset
```
```{r}
names(frag23_sub)[3:5]=c("S1","E2", "P1") ##Transform columns to shorter name
```
```{r}
tail(frag23_sub[order(x=-frag23_sub$E2),],10) #option1
tail(frag23_sub[order(x=-frag23_sub$E2),'Country'],10) #option2 #Produce a list of the top ten best countries on the data element Economy from 'frag23_sub'
```
```{r}
summary(object = frag23_sub)#Calculate basic summary statistics for the three data elements across all countries
```
```{r}
q3_Total=quantile(x = frag23_sub$Total, 
                  probs = 0.75, 
                  na.rm = TRUE) #Define the 3rd quartile data object, including to include values with nothing in them.
```
```{r}
q3_Total #calculate the 3rd quartile value
```
```{r}
cor(x=frag23_sub[,-c(1,2)]) #no 'Country', no "Total'#Calculate the correlations between "S1","E2", and "P1"
```
```{r}
library(corrtable)
corrtable::correlation_matrix(df = frag23_sub[,-c(1,2)]) #Install corretable package to find correlations between "S1","E2", "P1" and their "significance", with 1.0 showing Pearsen's coefficient
```
```{r}
lm(S1~P1+E2,data=frag23_sub)
model <- lm(S1 ~ P1 + E2, data = frag23_sub)
summary(model) #Create a regression plot of State Legitimacy and Economy by Demographic pressures to assess potential relationships
```
```{r}
hist(x = frag23_sub$P1) #Produce a plot for the State Legitimacy variable in a histogram format
```
```{r}
plot(x=frag23_sub$S1, y=frag23_sub$E2) #Produce the visual correlation between Demographic Pressures and Economy in black and white
```
```{r}
frag23_sub$Total>=q3_Total
frag23_sub$worstQt=frag23_sub$Total>=q3_Total #Define parameters for grouping values into buckets of True and False

```
```{r}
plot(frag23_sub$S1, 
     frag23_sub$E2,pch=20,
     col = as.factor(frag23_sub$worstQt)) #Applies color coding to the visual correlation to show countries in third quartile
```

```{r}
library(sjPlot)
plot_models(model) #Install SJ Plot and create a plot model
```
